intro: Micranthes pensylvanica var. tomentosa, commonly known as the hairy pipsissewa, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It is a member of the Geraniaceae family and is characterized by its small, clustered flowers and hairy, rounded leaves. The plant typically grows in moist, acidic soils in woodlands and along stream banks. Its foliage is often covered in fine, white tomentum, giving it a distinctive, fuzzy appearance. It is a low-growing perennial that produces red or pink flowers in late spring to early summer.
